technique when I was making the master to cast for this door frame I realized
very quickly that the usual tinfoil ball technique of denting foam to create
stone texture wasn't going to cut it for a high detailed resin cast I needed
texture that was more defined and more stone like and not just a light imprint
from the tin foil the tin foil works okay when you're just doing a quick
building that you're gonna paint up and that's that but I needed something
better so I started experimenting with different ways to Tek
during the XPS foam that would give me a more defined stone pattern and work
really well for casting and I came up with something that I thought was really
cool I have this engraving tool from hot wire foam Factory it's pretty much like
a little soldering iron with a metal tip that you can use to engrave in styrofoam
and it's a nifty little tool and it probably works really well for doing
kind of like haunted house props if you were doing big real sized tombstones and
you want to engrave lettering it would be great for that but I've always found
that the tip on it was a little bit too big and it melted a bit too much foam to
really be of use at a very small scale that I used when building buildings so
it kind of sits unused but when I started thinking about how to take the
aluminum foil texture to another level it dawned on me
if I were to take some foil and wrap it around the end of this tool it would
cause the tin foil to heat up then I could roll the piece over the foam and
indent that texture much deeper and it worked it worked really well so what I
did to get some really nice brickwork was I just cut a strip of XPS foam on my
procs on table to the dimension that I wanted then with a continuous stick I
textured it using the tin foil on the tool heated up and just started rolling
it down the piece and I was really happy with just how well it worked it's
important to make sure that this aluminum foil tin foil whatever is not
stuck on but can actually roll and spin on the piece and that way you can just
run it down like a wheel and get this excellent texture do all four sides of
your piece and then if you want to go over the corners lightly and hit those
two you will be left with this shaft that is really nicely textured you can
then cut in your individual bricks and then just one by one
the edges to kind of itch them with this again now this isn't the fastest thing I
wouldn't do this on a project where I needed 300 bricks but if you're gonna do
a nice showpiece or there's a spot on your building where you want to just
have a really nice accented stone this is a great way to do it or if like me
you're planning on casting your piece with us using silicone molds and plaster
or resin it really makes a big difference over just the normal aluminum
foil technique not only does it make the texture more defined
it also cauterizes the foam so all of a sudden your XPS foam that you're left
with is really really hard and rigid I would say it actually becomes more rigid
than even after you put Mod Podge on your foam this makes it really strong
and dense which is a nice bonus now I used this hot wire foam factory
engraving tool to accomplish this because I already had it and I will put
a link for it in the description of this video and I think it's already up on my
essential equipment store with a few other hot wire tools you don't need this
particular one I would wager that this technique would work just as well with a
soldering iron or a wood-burning engraver basically any hot tool that has
